content: over the past few months livestock has begun to vanish from the farms
surrounding Hill bottom so frequently that the farmers have started to worry
that they may not have enough meat to feed their families over the coming
winter you've been hired and paid well by a very desperate town master to get
to the bottom of these disappearances and put an end to them as quickly as
possible after some investigation you discover tracks leading from these farms
into the woods north of hill bottom tracks made by more than one person that
included drag marks they could easily have been made by pulling a large animal
through the mud after spending the better part of an afternoon following
these tracks through the woods you come upon a clearing it appears you have
found a long-forgotten Cemetery overlooked by a once beautiful Chapel by
the state of the bush and the weeds no one has used this place in decades you
would think this place was all but forgotten if it weren't for the faint
flickering candle light emanating through the ornate glass atop the chapel
what do you do hi guys welcome back to another episode
of black magic crafts just a little over a year ago I started in on this crazy
hobby the first session I ever ran took place in a cemetery in a swamp and
included a small chapel this here was the first bit of terrain I ever built a
simple building made of cardboard inspired heavily by the work of our
master DM Scotty after a year's worth of crafting I feel as though my techniques
and abilities have come a long way since that first simple building and in a way
I've come full circle and I've created another chapel a chapel
to replace this simple build it's a project that I talked about in the last
episode and one that I'm sure you've all seen many times by now in photographs on
both the DM Scotty's Facebook group and on the blackmagic Facebook page so I
think now is a good time for us to take a closer look at some of the techniques
and materials that I used to build it so let's zoom on in and take a look this is
my completed chapel build or as hankerin a drunken sand dragons has named it the
black magic cathedral like I mentioned in the last episode this build was not
something I had thought about in advance or planned it was something that I just
started making after a bit of a creative slump where I just pumped out a bunch of
bricks and had an idea to start building a
chapel so a lot of the decisions made on it weren't the best decisions and
weren't what I probably would have done if I had planned this out like I
normally do but you know what sometimes those mistakes are good and I just
rolled with it and I'm pretty happy with the end result even if there's some
small things I would have done differently this project like I said
started when I was out of ideas and I just started
making bricks and if you're wondering how I made those bricks go back and
watch the episode on ruins that's where I talk about how I make individual
bricks the only difference is on this one I made them thinner these ones I
actually made by cutting a few different thickness strips and then just cutting
them with a knife into different brick sizes and I threw them all in a tub and
mixed them all up and worked with them by randomly grabbing them which is what
gives this different depth in the brick surface I had someone comment on I think
one of the photos I posted this asking why I went with such different depths of
bricks because in reality you wouldn't see a lot of buildings or they'd be done
like this right like they would typically try to make them smooth and
even this isn't very realistic but I mean it's a weird Cathedral built for
D&D so realism isn't exactly the goal and I like the different protrusions
because at a distance on the table it adds a lot of depth and makes it look a
lot more 3d its accentuated right it hot takes the the washes and the paints
better and the way I kind of think of terrain is kind of like theatrical
makeup where you have to overdo it and then it reads more subtly from a
distance on the table so that's kind of my thought also I think it just makes it
look a little bit more like it belongs in a fantasy setting rather just than in
medieval Europe right you know what I mean made a bunch of bricks and by the
end of making them I said I'm going to make a chapel I started by just grabbing
some cardboard okay now normally you know I don't use
cardboard in my builds but the other goal with this build was to build it
completely out of scraps and garbage and all the foam used was little cut-offs
and random pieces that weren't really good for anything else
and I was actually running low on foam core so I had some cardboard I said
whatever I'm just going to try out this technique of like using them as a facade
kind of on on a frame I probably wouldn't use cardboard again in the
future I would just do this directly onto a structure made out of either foam
core or half-inch polystyrene like thick insulation foam but you know it worked
just fine if that's all you have available don't worry about it it's good
I just I don't really like the cardboard because once you put all the glue on it
it does shrink and warp you can see the front of this face on if you can tell
but it is a little bit bowed because of the glue causing the cardboard to warp I
kind of left it because I thought it looked okay on this I thought it looked
kind of interesting I started by grabbing a piece of cardboard and no
plan just cut out this front piece and I knew that I wanted something with a big
round window at the top so I cut out a circle and I wanted some kind of an
interesting door so the door I actually made I'll give you a closer look here
the the door is made out of insulation foam and I used a technique that I
believe I saw on the channel tws which is a really great terrain building
channel unfortunately all their videos are in German but even so they they show
a lot of the processes they use and you can pick up a lot of cool techniques
even if you don't speak German so anyways they in one of their videos
showed making an ornate door and basically what they did was they took a
piece of insulation foam and cut it to the shape of one half of a door and you
take that and you know if it's an inch thick or whenever you have that one side
of a door and then on the hot wire table you actually do all these little design
you scroll working things by just run freehand running it through on the hot
wire and it creates a really nice pattern but the real beauty of this
technique is that you then take that styrofoam piece and you make slices
and you get end up with two slices that are perfect mirror images because it
would be really difficult to make a mirrored image like this on the hot wire
table so that's what I ended up doing on this one I just want to test it out it
was the first and only time I've ever done that technique and it's not perfect
and if this was a planned build I probably would have done a few more
tries until I got one that was really clean and really perfect looking but at
that point in this build I was just messing around didn't really expect this
project to continue and end up where it did so in retrospect I wish I would have
put a little bit more effort into the door but despite that I think it still
looks pretty sweet anyway I had the front facade of this building cut out a
window did the door and then just started gluing bricks and once I had the
front piece I just continued and I made the rest of the frame of the building
out of the cardboard and just went ahead and glued bricks all over it and yeah I
really liked the way it turned out but when I go to making the sides I
thought it needed some extra embellishments so that's when I decided
to make these buttresses I think that's what they're called but hrus yeah
perhaps made those just half inch by half inch strips of insulation foam that
I then carved these brick lines into and those ones actually did right on the hot
wire table just laid it down and just tapped it into the wire quickly to etch
the line by doing that and then rotating it on the table there was a really fast
way to make a very square square bricks so I put those on the sides and
originally I did not have these ones on the front I had put a lot of effort into
making these bricks wrap around the corners nicely in a nice pattern
and once I had these on I looked at it and I went oh and needs something on the
front and back and at that point I kind of knew that I had wasted a bunch of
time doing the brickwork on the corners because this project would look much
nicer if I did these stone embellishments I was really hesitant to
cut out the brickwork that I just put a bunch of time into but I kind of live by
the motto of don't defend a mistake just because you spent a lot of time making
it I eventually convinced myself screw it
and I cut out the bricks on the four corners of the building scraped them all
off the glue had already dried so it was like a little bit difficult and I will
say that the eileenj tacky glue that I used to glue it all on works very well
but once I got it off I made these pieces glued them in and I was much
happier with the look of this building because originally without them it kind
of looked like a birdhouse and I wasn't too thrilled about that so I think this
helped to make it look a little bit more dynamic and once I got those on I knew
that this little this little chapel that I was envisioning was turning more into
a dark Cathedral and I ran with that theme as I continued on once I had
worked my way around the building with the brickwork and the buttresses I then
did a cardboard layer for the roof and I did some embellishments of on the
stonework just strips of polystyrene and then I got to the shingles and in the
past this has always been my most hated part of a build is doing the shingles
and in the past I've always done them out of card stock and it looks okay with
card stock it's nice because it's a nice thin material to use but it's hard to
get texture on it and it's a pain in the butt to cut all the shingles whether you
do them individually or in strips it makes no difference it's time-consuming
and annoying being inspired by John's shingles John for
dungeons and glue sticks I decided to try his method of making styrofoam
shingles I mean realistically that's right up my alley because I make
everything else at a styrofoam so I thought that that method was kind of a
match made in heaven so I went with it and I'm glad that I did because one it
was way quicker and I found it way more enjoyable than the cardstock so I think
from here on out that is my method there's a few different ways you can
approach cutting shingles out of styrofoam you can cut thin strips of
styrofoam and then cut the shingles out out of that and do different widths and
thicknesses or whatever but because I wanted these shingles to have that
rounded corner I didn't want these to look like wood shingles I wanted them to
look more like slate or clay shingles I wanted them to have these rounded
corners and that wouldn't be as easy to do with a strip this way where you cut
the shingles like this I didn't have to nip the corners which is part of the
reason the card stock shingles take so long so I came up with the idea of doing
it a little bit differently I made it was I think 3/4 by half inch sticks of
insulation foam and then I sliced it basically like deli meat sorry before I
sliced it I took that material and with a nail file I beveled the two of the
corner so I was able to just quickly bevel the two edges and it gave me
basically a tube that was the shape of distinguished Ingles that I could then
slice into thin slices and it very quickly gave me a whole bunch of
shingles with this shape I found that way faster like I would say this roof
compared to my other houses where I did card stock it maybe took me a third of
the time and it was more fun and I think it
actually has a better look to it I did this roof in I think one evening
Eileen's tacky glue just individually glued them on no grid or anything just
kind of eyeballed it and I was really happy with the way it turned out I think
it looks good I finished it off by putting this kind of stone cap on the
top and that is again like almost everything I do start with milling a
stick of insulation foam but then I then cut a rabbet in it so basically I got a
corner piece like an l-shaped piece of foam that sat right on top did a few
edges for some accent lines and that was that once the shingles were done I
didn't have these spikes on yet and I didn't have a base but for some reason I
decided to go into painting I guess I had thought that it was done and I just
went into painting it so I based the whole thing with my regular mixture of
matte Mod Podge mixed with black acrylic paint and I did that over the whole
thing to give it a protective coating and kind of give me the initial black
coat and usually when I do that I end up giving it another quick brushing of
black paint because the black paint mixed with the Mod Podge doesn't give
you a very solid covering but when I looked at it I kind of liked the way the
colors were showing through because well one I had made this out of two different
types of insulation foam some pink and some blue before anybody asks
there was no reason that these parts were made of a blue and these parts were
made out of pink like I said I was making this out of scrap material and
it's just kind of the way it worked out with what I grabbed there isn't much
difference between the pink and the blue there is a difference but it's not a
difference worth worrying about until you get to kind of high level building
if you're starting out in foam building just buy whatever you can it doesn't
really matter when I put the Mod Podge mixture on it was letting some of the
colors show through and it just so happened that the main bricks were the
pink and all the embellishments were the blue and I could kind of already see
that I wanted to do a two-tone color on the paint job and with those colors
showing through I thought that might actually help with the with the paint
give it a bit of more of a natural look rather than mixing in color to the
various stages of gray to make it look more realistic so I left it at that and
then I went directly into the base coat of color and I decided that the bricks
and the accents would be two different types of stone so all the accents I
painted with craft smart graphite is the color I like it for stuff like this
rather than just like the dark gray because it's a very blue gray it has a
bit of a different look to it so that's what I used on all the accents the
brickwork I decided to do in 8 tan these crafts mark 10 is the color and that
gave it a nice kind of dynamic look between the two different types of stone
and then the shingles I coated in a a purple and it was a purple that I mixed
myself so I can't tell you the color I made it from a mix of purple and
burgundy and I never showed you the 360 if you wanted to take a look at I'll
throw the back over here so you can see what that looks like for a bit
so once I had those three base coat colors on I then went ahead and did my
dry brushing I just used a first of all a light gray
dry brushing and I did that over all three colors I didn't do a separate dry
brush color on each just did the light gray over everything and then when that
was done I did the second dry brushing in a cream is basically like an
off-white again I did that over everything although I was careful to not
overdo it on the the darker accenting stones trying only to hit the edges and
going a little bit more heavy on the brickwork and the the shingles after
that I did my typical black wash which I have a video about if you haven't seen
it yet went over everything and what happens if you base coat your like brick
work in a tan at first you might think this is way too off like it's way too
light and it's way too brown but the tan with the black wash I find gives an
excellent brick color that is a nice change to just the typical two-tone gray
I really like the way the way it turns out after the black wash so then once
the black wash was done I wanted it to have a more weathered look like a little
bit mossy but I didn't feel like covering this in flock I didn't want the
moss to be you know a huge part of it I just wanted a little bit of implied damp
grime so I made a green wash I basically just took some water and some dark green
paint and I made a little batch of a wash that I went and put on a few small
spots in corners and stuff where water would sit it's not drastic it's just a
little accident you can see I did some right on underneath the window to the
door but it's very very subtle right but I think it's those little details that
take something from good to fantastic and my paint work is the part of terrain
building that I think could stand to have the most improvement I'm getting
pretty confident and happy with my sculpting abilities with styrofoam I
mean it can always be better but I think it's it's quite good i but I've always
felt that my paint work didn't do it justice and this may be the first
project where I really pushed hard to put a little bit more effort into the
paint job and I think it shows and I think I'm on the right path to getting
to be where I want to be with my paint work so once that was all dried I
realized oh this thing should have a base because with my buildings I don't
like having the roof lift off for a game play I like being able to take the whole
thing right off and being left with the floor plan so that you can play out your
scenario without the obstruction of the walls usually I just use a piece of
half-inch insulation foam and I pense crime in whatever Brooke whatever brick
or wood plankings I want so that's where I went the with
this initially basically just set this down on a piece of styrofoam and traced
out the shape a little bit oversized and I was left with this shape I started
drawing in my brickwork with a pen and after I looked at it I felt like the
scribed brickwork on the base did not look as good as the more 3d individual
brickwork on the building so I made the decision to layer this with individual
pieces just like the the building itself so I went around the
sides and I put in individual come on individual bricks
these ones are basically the same as the ones on the building except they are
thinner so I went all the way around did those bricks and then I did a border and
the stairs again each one of these are individual bricks and then for the floor
I wanted something a little bit different so I made this floor exactly
the same way I made the floor on one of my ruins which is by just making thin
slices from a square stock piece of insulation foam where I've slightly
sanded the corners to bevel them and I like that because it leaves these voids
and it kind of helps make the bricks look more individual rather than scribed
in and so once that was done this gave it the whole tinfoil ball texture and
then I had to paint this one and try to match it to the building and I actually
think that the paint job on the floor alone came out even better than on the
building and I really like the way this looks so much so that I think I'm going
to do another batch of dungeon tiles in this method because I really like the
individual brickwork I think it looks super sharp so the base was done the
building was done it didn't have the stained-glass window
yet but as I was looking at it I felt like it was just slightly missing
something and could stand to be a little bit more sinister in appearance and
that's when I got the idea to add all of these iron spikes and basically just
took some toothpicks poked holes in everything those nice thing about
styrofoam you can just poke into it and yep just cut some toothpicks and put
them in place with a dab of tacky glue and let it dry and they stiffened up
quite nicely I mean they're pretty deep they're probably about a half-inch
embedded into everything so they're pretty stable the only problem is that I
did this after everything was already painted so I then had to go in and paint
these without kind of screwing up the rest of the thing which would be fine
except there was like the little holes you know that revealed like unpainted
styrofoam a bit so it was a little bit annoying and it the paint didn't turn
out as good as it probably would have had I done this initially like I think
if I had put those in before painting you would have painted everything out
and it would have been a much more seamless kind of install if I paint it
all together but you know hey sometimes you just got to do what you got to do
the other thing I guess I didn't mention is the the paint job on the door I just
used a metallic paint it's like a brass or bronze paint mixed with a bit of
silver and the door handles are the same jewelry bits that I've used on I used on
my watch tower on the gate there so you can get those at the craft store at
Michaels in the think it's in like the bracelet section so once that was all
done I was left with only the stained glass window and throughout the whole
build I knew eventually I would have to make it and I knew that I wanted it to
be a pretty you know prominent feature and
that I didn't want to just do something crappy I wanted it to be pretty good in
my head I thought it would be a simple matter of just getting a piece of
plastic clear plastic and you know using marker paint of some kind to do the
stained glass but I needed something to do the the lead work the lines I wanted
those to be actually like 3d elements not just to be painted on lines so I
thought a bunch about how to do that you know I could have used toothpicks or
something but I thought that would be too big
I needed something pretty thin to do that so what I ended up coming up with
was I bought some very fine leather bracelet wire it's just in black and so
I got the design that I wanted I printed it out to scale to the same size of the
window and then I taped a piece of clear plastic over top and then I used that
leather bracelet wire and superglue to basically trace it out and I would just
take a line of superglue and trace it onto the pattern underneath and then
just embed the wire and it was a little bit tedious but actually didn't take
that long and it worked pretty well so then I was left with this window that
had the letting on it but no color and I did some tests with markers and paints
and everything I had did not work it the markers didn't apply to the plastic it
was too glossy any of the paints I had didn't work so what I ended up doing was
I knew that you could get like these stained glass kits for kids I knew that
they existed I went to the dollar store and I actually did find something that I
thought would work it was these these window decoration light catcher things
and I bought that and I tested it out and I thought that it would be perfect
so I took the paint that came with it put it into my little window that I just
put a bunch of effort into making the shape and it looked terrible
honestly guys it looked awful the paint applied really unevenly and then they're
putting on more than one coat to even it out it was not translucent enough to let
light through and I was not happy with it so I scrapped it and so I made a
second window did the lead work again which actually went really fast this
time because I'd already done it once I'm betting it only took me under half
hour to do but I again I needed a way to do the color and I had this set of
markers with all these different colors and I figure that's the best thing but I
won't draw on the plastic so I kind of looked through what I had to figure out
what would work and I found some tracing paper I had some opaque tracing paper
and I tested it out and the markers applied to it in a great way that gave
even color but also stayed very translucent and allowed light through it
so basically what I did was I had this plastic with the LED work on it and then
on a piece of tracing paper I did the coloring and I glued the two together
and it created a pretty darn good look it wasn't quite where I wanted it to be
because it still looked a little too bright and fake for this building but it
was close so I did that and then I decided on the leather work or on the
LED work leather strips to just take some metallic paints and dry brush it
and to make them look more like metal and I like the way that looked and then
I got kind of ballsy and like you know what I'm going to try and I took the
metallic paint and I just stippled it onto the plastic where the more the
colored glass would be and that was what made this really work because it made it
look one a little bit darker and grimy ER and it also gave it a lot more depth
and had like kind of this glittery kind of sparkly look to it and then I was all
done like that's it so I installed it
in into the back of the building but it's still needed glass like because
this LED work was on the surface so it was protruding and it didn't really make
sense so I figured the obvious thing to do would be to pour resin in here
so I took the the building stood it on end like this
and I poured in some acrylic water now I use the acrylic water that you saw me
use in my water feature tutorial it's the stuff from Walmart that is about the
third of the price of the enviro tech stuff at at michaels and it's like a
floral acrylic water and it's a great bargain but I've had a few problems with
it having used it more at one I've learned and other people have learned
the hard way that if you mix in any kind of color paint or ink to it it will not
cure so okay fine I put it in this thing I'm not mixing any paint in it it'll be
fine it'll cure and I just used it recently on another project and it was
fine I mixed it up got my ratios correct mix it up thoroughly transferred it into
a different cup mixed it again and then poured it and guess what two days later
it still hadn't cured I do not know what the problem with this stuff is I don't
know if has to do with the shelf-life or what but I did everything that I was
supposed to do to get the resin to cure properly and it didn't freakin cure a
bit of a disaster so anyway I dabbed out all the uncured resin and I was kind of
at square one again so I figured okay you know what screw
this stuff I'm not using anymore I'm gonna get the enviro Tex light stuff
because that's what lots of people use it works well you can mix stuff into it
and I've heard that it has a lot less problems with curing but I wanted to
finish this and I didn't have a chance to get to Michael's
where they sell it but I was at the dollar store and I remembered a video by
Luke's affordable paint service where he was doing water effects with dollar
store five minute epoxy basically the stuff in the syringe that it mixes and
dries in five minutes that you would use as an adhesive and he used it for water
effects and it seemed to look pretty good at dries clear I figured for a buck
I'm going to try it mostly because it was something that would cure really
fast and then I could just have it done and feel good about it and move on I was
not mentally up for another you know 72-hour wait for or whatever for resin
to cure after having a failure I just wanted to see a cured and done so I did
a test with that and it worked great so that's what I did I mixed that up and I
poured it in and it's very thick to work with it's not I wouldn't recommend it
for stuff where you don't want to where you wanted to light or perfectly fly and
not get on anything you know it's very very viscous so I poured it in and I
kind of had to work it a bit with a with a stick to get it to the point where it
was kind of evenly coverage but then after a minute it evened out enough and
it dried fast like within five minutes it was done and this thing is it's hard
and it dried perfectly clear so I'm happy with it I think it was a great
solution for a dollar and then after that I just needed to put some lights in
it and like I mentioned before I have a bunch of parts coming in the mail to do
integrated lighting but they haven't all arrived yet but this is a big open space
so I figured I'd just use a tea light and that's what I did so inside you can
see just this cardboard frame very simple and I just took a tea light and I
cut a piece of styrofoam to hold it in place
right and it basically projects light out the front real simple real easy I
think once I get my all my parts for lighting I'll probably run some
integrated lighting into this just because I have so much coming that I'll
be able to do kind of as much as I want so that is that after everything was at
that point and done one heavy coat of Minwax polyurethane as I always do
because I love the way it makes this stuff look I like the slightly wet look
it really enhances the colors add some protection and good to go now I just
have to think of a adventure to run for my party
utilizing this I know that some of you guys will see this and implement some of
this stuff into your own builds if you do please share it with me on the
blackmagic page make a post on there I like seeing it and of course most of you
are on DM Scotty's crafts and games Facebook page and you like to post up
there so if you guys post anything on there that is in any way inspired by
some of the stuff I've shown you please tag or write black magic crafts in it so
that I don't miss it and so that we can turn some more people onto the channel
also if you want to use a chapel like this in your game but you don't have the
time or energy to build it good news hankering over drunk ins and Dragons
just released on Drive Thru RPG and index card set which is basically I
can't remember how much maybe a hundred hand-drawn different dungeon and
adventuring elements on index card size that you download you print out and you
can lay out a dungeon or an adventurer using those and it's pretty cool he
actually made one of the cards is the black magic cathedral so if you go over
to drive through RPG and download that set and print it out you can implement a
black magic cathedral without having to build one I will put the link in the
video description below and please go check it out support
drunken xand dragons because without his channel Blackmagic craft probably would
not exist as a channel so the more love you can give them the better
and as always Blackmagic craft could use your support so please like this video
leave a comment below and if you haven't already subscribed hit subscribe tell
your friends and you know what if you want to be part of the black magic
community go over to Facebook look at the Facebook page there like it comment
all those other good things so anyway until next time guys peace have a good
one
